problem: There are 80 students in a school. If 25 students are absent, how many students are present in the school? [kid]

hints.description: This is a problem that involves subtraction.
Imagine you have 80 chairs, but some of them are empty.
The phrase "25 students are absent" tells you how many chairs are empty.

questions.question: Let’s set up our problem...
options: 80 students - 25 absent students = __ present students. |  80🙋 - 25🙋= __🙋  (correct answer)

hints.description: Variables are like labeled containers that hold values.  [Variables are like containers for numbers]
A good formula uses easy-to-remember variables.  That way, we can allocate more brain power to reasoning. [fun equation]
Use the numbers from the story problem to set up the equation.
Remember to subtract the number of absent students from the total number of students.
You should end up with a number that tells you how many students are present.

problem: A pizza has 12 slices. If you eat 3 slices, how many slices are left? [pizza]

questions.question: The phrase “eat 3 slices” suggests this is a _____ problem.

hints.description: What mathematical operation would you use to find out how many slices are left after eating some of them?
You are trying to find the difference between the total number of slices and the slices you ate.
If you have 12 slices and you eat 3, which operation will help you find the remaining amount?

questions.question: Start the show, set up the problem and let the solutions flow. | Use variable names.

hints.description: Variables are like labeled containers that hold values.  [Variables are like containers for numbers]
A good formula uses easy-to-remember variables.  That way, we can allocate more brain power to reasoning. [fun equation]
Think about the proper names for the variables that represent the initial number of slices, the eaten slices, and the remaining slices.
Consider what you're trying to find the remaining slices after some are eaten. Which equation most clearly represents that?
Remember that the problem involves pizza slices, not donuts or bites.

questions.question: Time to get sharp and plug in the harp! (plug in the known values)

hints.description: Pretend each variable is a cup with tape on it that says the name of the cup.  You’re just dropping in the numbers into the cup. [It’s easy to plug in variables]
What are the given values for startingSlices and eatenSlices in the problem?

Remember that you're trying to find the remaining slices after eating 3 out of the 12 initial slices.

problem: If 8 friends have 24 cookies and want to divide them equally, how many cookies will each friend get? [cookie]

questions.question: This is a ______ problem.

hints.description: You can think of a division problem as a grouping job. You’re just grouping 24 cookies (🍪) into 8 piles (one pile for each friend). Each friend should have the same amount so it’s fair!

questions.question: How many cookies are there total?
options: My friend Tommy ate all of them 🙁

hints.description: Re-read the story problem and pay special attention to the total cookies.

questions.question: How many 8’s can you fit into 24?

hints.description: Try counting by 8 until you can get 24.
if you need to write it out, start by adding 8+8, then keep adding 8 to the number you get.

problem: If you have $30 and you buy a toy that costs $15, how much money will you have left? [discount]

questions.question: This is a ______ problem

hints.description: Re-read the story problem and pay special attention to the ‘buy a toy’ part.

problem: A rectangle has a length of 10 inches and is 6 inches wide. What is the perimeter of the rectangle? [rectangle]

questions.question: Time to party and set it up smarty

hints.description: Perimeter is the total length of the boundary or outer edge of an object.  A rectangle has 4 sides and the question tells us the lengths.  You can just add them up!

questions.question: Let’s add it up and fill our cup.

hints.description: When a problem has a word like ‘inches’ or ‘feet’, this is called the UNIT. Make sure that you remember to include that in your answer!
You can also solve this using another equation: Perimeter = 2✖️(length + width)
